I picked up this book because I was intrigued by its cover and title, of course! On the contrary, it stayed on my shelf until very recently, when I picked it up to escape a reading slump.

And boy oh boy, how cool it was to finally dive in. Though short, it carries a profound message about our thoughts, actions, and mind. I‚Äôm sure by now everyone knows we have thousands of thoughts a day. It‚Äôs impossible not to think, but it is possible not to think about our thoughts‚Äîget it?

Our suffering begins when we overthink our thinking, fixating on particular thoughts. The book explains that if we can just stop thinking about our thoughts, we may end much of our suffering. Our thoughts are a complex mix of experiences, biases, fears, and aspirations, shaped by our past, societal influences, and upbringing. You‚Äôll be surprised to realise how many of these thoughts have no real relation to reality‚Äîmost are illogical, just patterns we‚Äôve inherited.

The solution? Simple, though not easy. We must stop overthinking our thoughts. We‚Äôll always have opinions and beliefs about everything, but we need to resist the urge to spiral into further thoughts about those opinions. By practicing detachment, we can observe our thoughts as they pass by, like clouds in the sky, without identifying with them or letting them control our emotions and actions.

This practice allows us to reclaim our power of choice. When we stop believing every thought that enters our mind, we regain the ability to decide which ones matter and which ones don‚Äôt.

Ultimately, this book was a profound discovery for me. It deepened my understanding of thoughts and emotions. No thought is inherently positive or negative‚Äîit‚Äôs us who categorise them. It‚Äôs a great read that encourages us to look beyond the surface of our thoughts, approach them with healthy skepticism, and live in a more balanced, empowered way.

Review_Title: Through perfect anecdotes and practical exercises attain a deeper understanding of your thoughts
Review_Body:
In a world saturated with information and distractions, finding a book that not only captures your attention but also offers profound insights into the human experience is a rare gem. This transformative piece invites readers to embark on a journey of self-discovery, challenging the very fabric of their thoughts and beliefs.
Beyond mere entertainment, books have the power to impact our lives in profound ways. Joseph Nguyen's book is a testament to the transformative potential of literature, particularly in the realm of mindful living.
In a society where the constant chatter of social media and the hustle and bustle of daily life often drown out our inner voices, a book that encourages introspection is a breath of fresh air. "Don‚Äôt Believe Everything You Think" serves as a guide to understanding the intricate dance between our thoughts and emotions, offering tools for cultivating a more mindful and purposeful existence.
The title itself hints at the core message of the book - the pivotal role our thoughts play in shaping our experiences. Nguyen skillfully weaves together ancient wisdom and modern psychology to explore the roots of suffering and how our own minds can either perpetuate or alleviate it. Readers are taken on a journey through the intricacies of the human mind, with each chapter offering insights and practical exercises to foster self-awareness. Nguyen's writing is accessible and engaging, making complex concepts digestible for readers at various stages of their mindfulness journey.
The book encourages readers to adopt a more mindful way of thinking, emphasizing the importance of being present in each moment. Through personal anecdotes, philosophical reflections, and practical exercises, Nguyen guides readers towards a deeper understanding of their own thought processes and the impact they have on their overall well-being.
As you delve into the pages of this insightful book, you may find that the key to ending unnecessary suffering lies within the very thoughts you choose to believe.

The book has a strong central point which is about differentiating between thoughts and thinking. I like that. There are really good insights around that and it is supported with practical and acceptable thought experiments. But the book just stops right there. Nothing new or anything more insightful beyond conveying thinking affects your life.

If you're writing about something psychological, spiritual, and a big game changer in anyone's life, then you must give some real-life examples apart from the age-old Zen stories.

Let's take the Psychology of money, Housel explains the battle of Stalingrad to make you understand the preparation you must have for an emergency fund. That's all it is. I can never forget both the battle and the emergency fund. Take Atomic Habits, Clear would've explained the importance of habits with a simple equation of getting better by 1% every day and moves on to explain other parts of Habits. That's how the book should've been structured. You just say less to give a bigger impact and move on to other areas of thinking and thoughts instead of simply reiterating the thoughts are good, thinking is bad, and so on.

This book has good content, but I won't recommend reading this because an ordinary medium blog or a Quora answer can substitute what Nguyen wrote for 160 pages. Of course, there are a lot of positive things in this book but those are not something that will inspire you or make you go wow I should follow this!

I won't recommend this book, but I'll appreciate the importance it gave to the thoughts and thinking.

Do not pick this book.
